posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.sub: Why did it take so long for criticism of feminism to emerge in earnest?
posts.com:
The feminist movement is over one hundred years old, and yet it's only in the past ten years that it has come under any remotely sustained criticism or pushback in the West.

Even outside the West, in places like Japan and South Korea, South and Southeast Asia, and much of Africa, feminist ideas, laws, and thinking mostly gained ground even if somewhat slowly throughout the 20th century (voting rights, education, increased rights for women in divorce, more rights for women in physical and sexual abuse cases, access to contraception and abortion, financial autonomy, etc.).

Feminism has been so stupefyingly successful that its opponents are forced to cling to tiny victories, like the Taliban returning to power in Afghanistan, the election of a president somewhat frosty towards feminism in South Korea, abortion being returned to the states by the US Supreme Court, etc.

Meanwhile, whole regions are still becoming more and more feminist all the time, more and more feminist norms in education, dating, marriage...

>>14360724
>Why the fuck did the USA stop the brits and french occupying the suez? Was it just to flex?
The Suez Crisis was orchestrated by the British, French, and Israelis without the US, as the Americans wouldn't back such a blatantly imperialist expedition (even if it wouldn't been a pragmatic one for keeping markets open), as the Americans believed Egyptian ownership of the Suez Canal to not be such a massive threat to them (only commodity of significant value to the US passing through here was Saudi oil, America was still virtually self-reliant in most other markets at this point, and was a massive exporter to Europe). As they weren't too concerned with the canal changing ownership, they didn't consider Egypt to be a significant flashpoint, and witht the Soviets threatening war over this, the Americans weren't willing to have the Third World War over Suez.
It wasn't fear of pushing Nasser to the Soviets, it was fear of war over a place that didn't concern American hegemony over Western Europe, and in fact, the British and French losing at Suez would make them more reliant on the US, increase the rate of decolonisation, and hoped for de-escalation in Arab-Israeli relations and the status quo there.
France would still cling to its empire, developing more subtle means overtime, especially in Africa, and weren't too impacted by the crisis, and had fewer interests east of Suez by that point. Britian on the otherhand, was massively embarrassed, and no longer monopolised the major trade routes of the Old World, and would grow increasingly dependent on the American market for their goods as opposed to the Commonwealth. As for Israel, this one didn't work, but the US would never let Israel fall and didn't consider its Arab neighbours competant enough to seize the nation.

Also I'm basing it on reading the relevant chapters in his books, not just the maps.

First of all, he has a strange view of what happened in the Neolithic. First issue is that he (and other academics) didn't recognize the Early/Pre-Pottery Neolithic, so for them the Neolithic (and agriculture etc) started around 7000 BC, what we now know as Pottery/Late Neolithic.
Now because it seems to spread along two axes in Europe around the same time, he decided it must mean two distinct races that started colonizing Europe in the late paleolithic must have spread it or maybe developed it independently, the meds and the alpines. The northern and southern expansions, although he's rather wrong about the exact trajectory.
He considers the alpines to be descended from an asiatic (specifically armenoid) squat "roundhead" populations, I think fair-skinned but otherwise of dark complexion that emerged in the caucasus/persian region, meanwhile he considers the meds are similarly dark but brown-skinned semitic goblins who were all over the middle east (minus anatolia and persia), north africa, south europe and even the dravidians in india. Also britain to explain the supposed "irish negro" phenotype.
Now this is quite contrary to our understanding of Early European Farmers, I think Sardinia is the clearest example (pure Med in his view, while we now know it's the closest thing we have to pure EEFs)
I forgot where he thinks nordics come from exactly but they were skirting the inhabitable edges of the glacial zones in Europe, naturally they were pale blonde tall strong and blue-eyed etc, and the origin of all those traits in europe and else. the purest "Teutonic" type was in scandinavia but they were all over the baltic, Russia, the steppes. Those are his proto-Aryans.

>>14360839
It wasn't. There was a constant string of mass murders and war crimes committed by American troops throughout the entire decade of American involvement in the war.
Every major American unit in Vietnam, down to the brigade, had "incidents" wherein Vietnamese civilians were abused, murdered, and raped. The only thing exceptional about My Lai was its scope, killing hundreds at once was a step too far that couldn't be hidden. But the brutalization and killings of civilians was routine.
Even the most cursory examination of the evidence shows this, and it isn't even hidden or disputed. The US military's own analysis showed that during Operation Speedy Express, for example, 5000-7000 of the 10000 Vietnamese killed were civilians. The most outrageous stories there coming from the helicopter and light plane crews that admitted to military investigators that they constantly just murdered anyone they saw for any reason they could think of.
The ubiquitous search and destroy missions were much more up close and personal. Many times these were just covers for the wholesale destruction of a village that happened to be close to a place where a Viet Cong ambush had taken place, or where a GI had gotten injured or killed by a trap or mine. Troops bombed the village, rolled in, burned the houses, killed the livestock, raped the women, and then killed them along with anyone else they could get their hands on. I suggest you read Jamie Henry's account of one such attack. The highlight is really something, and it was attested to by multiple witnesses to military investigators. Or you could read about Roy Bumgarner, who was known as a murderer among troops and was convicted of manslaughter after gunning down four civilians and blowing their heads up with a grenade to teach some new recruits how to conduct themselves.
I can't do the extent of the violence justice, there is too much and I get too angry. I highly advise you look into this, what happened in Vietnam was pure evil.

The US had an official strategy of sending death squads/basically serial killers to murder any civilian suspected of having contact with the VC. If you wanna get schizo-pilled read Programmed to Kill and the links between the Phoenix Program, MKULTRA and the massive increase in serial killer incidents in the US before and during the Nam era.

>The program, which lasted from 1967 to 1972, was designed to identify and destroy the Viet Cong (VC) via infiltration, torture, capture, counter-terrorism, interrogation, and assassination. The CIA described it as "a set of programs that sought to attack and destroy the political infrastructure of the Viet Cong." The Phoenix Program was premised on the idea that North Vietnamese infiltration had required local support within noncombat civilian populations, which were referred to as the "VC infrastructure" and "political branch" that had purportedly coordinated the insurgency.

>Throughout the program, Phoenix "neutralized" 81,740 people suspected of VC membership, of whom 26,369 were killed, and the rest surrendered or were captured.

>The Phoenix Program was heavily criticized on various grounds, including the number of neutral civilians killed, the nature of the program (which critics have labelled as a "civilian assassination program,"[7]) the use of torture and other coercive methods, and the program being exploited for personal politics. Nevertheless, the program was very successful at suppressing Viet Cong political and revolutionary activities.[7] Public disclosure of the program led to significant criticism, including hearings by the US Congress, and the CIA was pressured to shut it down. A similar program, Plan F-6, continued under the government of South Vietnam.

It helps that the ruling party there professes itself to be a Marxist party and its president-for-life is talks all the time about Marxism being good and that you should read Marx.

But much of what Marx was presented in his writings is kinda commonplace now, it's so entrenched.... lol. You don't get sociology without Marx, you can't really write history now without being influenced by him. There's still an entire neoliberal hegemony on culture designed to obfuscate this, but there was more than "let's make revolution" (although that was also the point), it's just that philosophers of that era (especially German ones) weren't known for their brevity, so if you dive into Capital it won't really read as revelatory as it may have in the context of its own time.

But if the /pol/yps who say that Marxism is "Talmudic" are right about something, then it's because there isn't a "right path" for reading the texts, and nobody but the most vulgar of dorks will look down on you for not having read something, because no one and I mean *no one* has read all this stuff.

A big part of the critique of utopian socialism too is that it's un-dialectical to jump to socialism without wrestling with the fact that you're "in" capitalism and have to figure out how to use capital's own contradictions to get to something else. Revolutionary situations emerge from unavoidable pressures within the capitalist system forcing crisis and that's what gives opportunities to make sudden leaps.

Marxism is also what gives minor strands of political thought which hadn't made an exceptional mark on the political landscape before suddenly have the right tools and the right voice to operate in whatever situation they've been thrust into and that allows them to outmatch previously unassailable forces -- all you've got to do is use Marxist analysis and knowledge built in struggle now to be confident that you can be that force.

>>14368379
The point really is to avoid idealism and utopianism and, instead, use a materialist outlook and actually learn from the past so that you can calibrate strategies accordingly with self-criticism.

To use an analogy, think of the computer you're using right now. You have a button on the screen you press and it plays a ping noise, but that's not really what it's doing, to learn more about that you have to peel it back and look at the code. But that's also not what it's really doing, there's an entire operating system down to the material reality of the computer being a bunch of magnetic bits being flipped by an array of logic gates and it's all made out of copper and silicon.

So the implication for socialism is that it requires some more understanding than just going "well you click a button and it goes ping." Or regarding capitalism, the program has some bug in it that makes it break, or perhaps it's doing something nefarious and hidden, then the only way you could discover what the hell this thing is actually doing is to peel back those layers and then put them back on with a new understanding. Dialectical process:

>Surface appearance ⤍ hidden essence ⤍ truth behind the surface appearance

Or:

>Machine that goes ping ⤍ code that does a lot of fucky things without telling you ⤍ Machine mails your porn to all your peers and goes ping

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14369498
There is a widespread myth that Moors, a term used to refer to Muslims of North African and Iberian origin, introduced the practice of bathing and the use of soap to Europe during the Middle Ages. This myth is often used to portray Moors as more civilized or hygienic than Europeans at the time. However, there is no historical evidence to support this claim.

In fact, the ancient Romans, who occupied much of Europe, were known for their elaborate public baths and hygiene practices. The Moors, who ruled parts of Iberia (present-day Spain and Portugal) from the 8th to the 15th centuries, inherited and built upon the Roman legacy of public baths. However, the Moors did not invent the concept of bathing or soap-making.

It is possible that the myth of Moors introducing bathing to Europe arose due to the influence of the Moors on Iberian culture during the Middle Ages. The Moors brought with them many scientific and cultural advances, including the study of mathematics, astronomy, and medicine, as well as the cultivation of crops such as sugarcane, cotton, and citrus fruits. However, the idea that they introduced the practice of bathing to Europe is not supported by historical evidence.

The myth has been circulating for at least several centuries.

One possible source of the myth is the medieval concept of the "Moorish bath," which was a type of public bath that was popular in Europe during the Middle Ages. These baths were often associated with the Moors and were thought to be based on the baths used in Muslim cultures. However, the concept of the "Moorish bath" was more likely a product of European imagination and cultural exchange with the Moors, rather than an accurate reflection of actual practices in Muslim cultures.

The city was located on the west bank of the Volga River, which made it a key transportation route for moving goods and troops. The desire for access to raw materials and markets led to tensions and conflicts over the control of territories such as Africa and Asia. This competition also contributed to the arms race between the major powers, as they sought to build up their military capabilities in order to protect and expand their economic interests.

Many European countries had taken on large amounts of debt in order to finance their industrialization and military expansion. The fear of defaulting on these loans added to the tensions between the powers, as they sought to ensure that they would be able to repay their debts.

The economic tensions between the powers were exacerbated by the system of alliances that had developed in Europe. The complex network of alliances, which were largely motivated by economic considerations, led to a situation in which a conflict between any two powers could quickly escalate into a full-scale war involving all of the major powers.

Economic tensions and competition played a significant role in the conflicts that preceded the war and helped to create the conditions that made it possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't know about this particular case but it's far more complex than "their iron is cheaper than ours." I can think of several reasons iron would be cheaper to import than produce domestically:
- They may not have has the proper industries established to mine and process ore, both of which require skilled labor and robust infrastructure to perform.
- They may also have not had easy access to other essential resources such as coal with which to actually do the refining.
- The iron in Korea may also have been of lower quality, if it was present at all.
- Labor may have been more expensive domestically

These are reasons anything could be cheaper to import, but you could probably find specifics on each that relate to Korea with a little digging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"The following dissertation concerning the Trinity, as the reader ought to be informed, has been written in order to guard against the sophistries of those who disdain to begin with faith, and are deceived by a crude and perverse love of reason.

Now one class of such men endeavor to transfer to things incorporeal and spiritual the ideas they have formed, whether through experience of the bodily senses, or by natural human wit and diligent quickness, or by the aid of art, from things corporeal; so as to seek to measure and conceive of the former by the latter. Others, again, frame whatever sentiments they may have concerning God according to the nature or affections of the human mind; and through this error they govern their discourse, in disputing concerning God, by distorted and fallacious rules. While yet a third class strive indeed to transcend the whole creation, which doubtless is changeable, in order to raise their thought to the unchangeable substance, which is God; but being weighed down by the burden of mortality, while they both would seem to know what they do not, and cannot know what they would, preclude themselves from entering the very path of understanding, by an over-bold affirmation of their own presumptuous judgments; choosing rather not to correct their own opinion when it is perverse, than to change that which they have once defended.

And, indeed, this is the common disease of all the three classes which I have mentioned — viz., both of those who frame their thoughts of God according to things corporeal, and of those who do so according to the spiritual creature, such as is the soul; and of those who neither regard the body nor the spiritual creature, and yet think falsely about God; and are indeed so much the further from the truth, that nothing can be found answering to their conceptions, either in the body, or in the made or created spirit, or in the Creator Himself." -St. Augustine

https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/130101.htm

There is a written tradition, going back to the early sixth century, that says the first Anglo-Saxons in Britain were mercenaries who mutinied against their British employers and began seizing the island by force. The archaeology seems to say something quite different. The earliest Saxon cemeteries, dating to the mid fifth century and found in the Thames Valley and Essex, seem to be of ordinary farmers. These are poor people, buried without weapons. Their settlements are undefended, and they seem to have existed side-by-side with equally undefended settlements of ordinary Romano-British farmers. There is also considerable evidence for contact between the two peoples: hundreds of British place names survived, the genetics seems to show substantial intermarriage, many old community boundaries were maintained. The culture we call Anglo-Saxon seems to have emerged gradually from the mixing of British and barbarian elements, and not until nearly a century later do we have much evidence for Anglo-Saxon warriors, especially warrior aristocrats

There's very little Gaulish influence on French too, which is kind of shocking considering the Frankish influence on French.
The conclusions we can draw are that Celtic languages probably weren't particularly different from either Germanic or Italic languages, particularly in these earlier stages.

The further back you go the more similar all these languages become until they are just the same language, Proto-Indo-European.
They hadn't really been separate languages for such a long time before they began colliding together again and they probably still remained in a language contact zone through trade and other interactions.

There's also the very realistic scenario that regions that were ruled by Celtic elites and dynasties may well not have been Celtic-speaking among the common population which may have consisted largely of slaves and conquered peoples from other ethnolinguistic groups.

>>14361956

>dwindled back into barbarity

I disagree. A lot of this perception is outdated archaeology written on a lot of Victorian assumption that the Britons (Welsh) just sucked and the Anglo Saxons (English) were giggachads who took over. Archaeology today indicates something really different.

Romano British had better written Latin then most of Europe at this point (that fell to barbarians) to the point they had colourful linguistic word play in their monuments. Literacy was not confined to the monastery elite of this period -- check out the Caldey Stone. Many of these stones litter Britain and were often written in complex Latin verse with hidden meanings and the ability to read backward

Hadrian's wall was being garrisoned and expanded upon, as were cities in places like York which included production increase (such as pottery). They also traded with and communicated with the Byzantines during the Justinian period. The Byzantines would not send emissaries half way around the known world to a country they thought had become a backwater. They came to a economically independent group which displays that the East was interested in the West. They were looking for descents of Romans and found them - who know the same languages, rituals, customs and ideas etc.

There were dozens of monastic monasteries during this Dark Age which produced learned monks like Gildas who often wrote in sophisticated flowery Latin for an equally sophisticated audience (fellow Britons) as his works are filled with classical references. The Irish monks told the Pope Gregory the Great to check out his works. These weren't just isolated monks hidden away in damp ruined chapels. It indicates these people had scholars who were in touch with philosophy and religious discussion of their time period and in contact with the rest of the world.

The Romano British might have devolved into petty Kingdoms during this period (as did the whole west empire) but they didn't revert to pre-Roman Britain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's a brainbuster for you. I'm just going to refer to the bread to make this easier to type.

Transubstantiation is the doctrine that the substance of the bread changes into the flesh of Christ, but it retains the accidents, or the physical properties of bread. So it looks like break, smells like bread, tastes like bread, etc., but it is actually not bread. It is the flesh of Christ and it is not bread.

Now, the accidents of the bread do not transfer over and become proper to the new substance. So bread is made of wheat, but it is incorrect to say that Christ's flesh is made of wheat. Get it? His flesh is there only in substance but not in its proper accidents.

Here is the problem: physical location is an accident. It is the point of space occupied by physical mass -- this is a physical property, and it is a property that is proper to the bread. So when the substance of the bread changes, this accident of physical location also does not transfer over to the flesh -- if it did you would end up with the problem regarding his flesh thus being made of wheat. These are both physical properties and neither transfer.

So transubstantiation offers no way to actually locate the flesh in any particular place. The substance has changed to flesh, but the physical location cannot transfer and be proper to the flesh. The accidents of bread are on the altar, but these do not pertain to the flesh. The doctrine is intrinsically absurd.

The same doctrine, however, suggests the further question, whether such accidents may not be separable from substance. Reason alone offers no positive arguments for such separability. The most it can do is to show that separability involves no inherent contradiction, and hence no absolute impossibility; the Omnipotence that endows substance with the power of supporting accidents can, it is claimed, supply some other means of support. Nor would the accidents thus separated, and supernaturally supported, lose their character as accidents, since they would still retain their essential property, i.e. natural exigence of inhesion. Of course the intrinsic possibility of such separation depends solely on the supernatural interference of God, nor may it extend to all classes of accidents. Thus, e.g., it is absolutely impossible for vital faculties, or acts, to exist outside their natural subjects, or principles. Theorists who, like the Cartesians, deny the objective, distinct entity of all accidents have been obliged to reconcile this negation with their belief in the Real Presence by maintaining that the species, or accidents, of bread and wine do not really remain in the Eucharist, but that after Consecration God produces on our senses the impressions corresponding to the natural phenomena. This theory obviously demands a seemingly unnecessary multiplication of miracles and has at present few if any serious advocates."

>>14369808
>okay but where do we decide to draw the line between various subraces even?
This is the point of the field. You can use a combination of cluster algorithms etc., but ultimately linguistic become important too if you want to study peoples.
>also, unrelated: are occasional matings between subraces dysgenic?
No. Dysgenics usually occurs when two races don't share genes. E.g. in your case every other European you meet will have the same genes you do of a different allele. Alleles determine the phenotype of your kids. Many ethnicities without European roots will not have an allele present on their chromosomes corresponding to all your alleles. Therefore even dominat alleles might not get expressed (or vice versa recessive alleles might get expressed risking one that are linked to disease), the chromosome length might be shifted and so histones are not properly binding introns etc. this leads to all kinds of issues related to chromosome instability like premature aging, lowered fertility, cancer etc.

The risks in humans are not as well studied as in other animals for obvious reasons.

>for us, there is one God, the Father, from whom are all things and to/for whom we live, and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom are all things and through whom we live.
Paul is evoking the Jewish monotheistic confession laid out in the opening line of the daily prayer known as the shema:
>hear, O israel, the LORD/Yhwh our God, the LORD/Yhwh is One.”
This is a self conscious identification of Jesus (Kyrios) with the four-lettered, ineffable name of God (Yhwh), where the Lord Jesus Christ is ascribed a role in creation. It is also interesting that this Christological reworking of the confession in 1 Cor 8:6 has 26 words, which is the numerical value of Yhwh and an important number in Scripture.

>>14370106
But that is not what Paul is saying here. For example, if a gangster named Percival Grabonski had the nickname of “Mailman Mike,” we would consider that as an exclusive single unitized title of two words. We might even say, “There is only one 'Mailman Mike'; he’s unique.” The whole thing (both words: “Mailman” and “Mike”) taken together as a multi-worded, but ‘unitized,’ whole, then, is the complete title.

However, if we knew a young man named Mike who delivered our mail every morning, we might tell someone, “This town has only one mailman, Mike.”

In this case the title is “mailman” alone, and “Mike” is an appositive or identifier added to that single title to further identify which “mailman.”

Since it is not an exact exclusive title, it could even be phrased differently: “Mike is our only mailman;” “only one letter carrier, Mike;” “only one mail deliverer, Mike;” etc. When the writer (or speaker) intends it in this ‘title with appositive’ manner, the phrase may be understood as actually saying: “only one mailman, [and that is] Mike.”

posts.name: JWanon
posts.com:
>>14370106
On the other hand, the gangster’s unitized title will not be phrased differently. He wouldn’t be called “Mailman Mike” one time and “Mike the Letter Carrier” or “Mike the Postal Person” the next time. His exclusive, distinguishing unitized title is “Mailman Mike” and that won’t change (even though he may pick up additional, different titles, e.g. “Percy the Purse-snatcher”).

In one case, then (e.g., “mailman, Mike”), we have a single-word title (e.g., “mailman”) followed by a word or words (sometimes even set off by commas in English) which identify that individual. In the other case (e.g., “Mailman Mike”) we have a full title composed of two or more words which must be taken together as a complete unit (“unitized”). Don't forget that in the original manuscripts there was no punctuation or Capitalization. These have been added by modern translators as they see fit.

Toilets =/= indoor plumbing. There's two ways this was done without plumbing. Either you have a pot in the toilet that servants would have to take out and clean, or you would have the toilet facing an exterior wall, so it would dump outside of the building:
>The toilets of a castle were usually built into the walls so that they projected out on corbels and any waste fell below and into the castle moat. Even better, waste went directly into a river as is the case of the latrines of one of the large stone halls at Chepstow Castle in Wales, built from the 11th century CE. Some castles, such as the 11th-century CE Corfe Castle in Dorset, England had latrine shafts emptying directly in the courtyard or bailey while still others hung conveniently over a cliff face, as at Peveril Castle in Derbyshire, England, built in 1176-1777 CE.

He was brilliant. He was an outstanding diplomat. He had to be – his life was hanging by a thread from a very young age. His powerful grandmother adored little Alex, but hated his father and wanted Alexander to ascend to the throne instead of him. In this situation one wrong move could cost him his life real quick. The fact that he managed to survive tells us he was a very shrewd and clever man. Not only did he survive, but he also took part in the coup against his father without making it obvious, and later quietly removed from power the men who carried it out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14366211

I've been Reading "Russia Against Napoleon" by Dominic Lieven, and he has an interesting take on Alexander; basically Alexander's father and grandfather had both been overthrown and murdered (though Alexander had a hand in his dad's overthrow), and Alexander was acutely aware that there were factions in Russia that could, would and had overthrow and kill the Tsar. As a result, Alexander made a point of never letting anyone know what he was thinking, and made sure to present everyone with whatever he thought they would want to hear. Lieven's thesis is basically that a leader who was deranged or decided things at random could not have pulled off the diplomatic/military manoeuvring after Austerlitz nor held popular discontent in check during the retreat to and burning of Moscow during Napoelon's invasion.

Russian state structure is predicated on men and not laws, this means the higher your position the less constraints you have on your behavior as there are less and less people above you that you have to not piss off. Once you reach the top there is nothing to keep you grounded, Western Europe had the church and proto-parliaments of lower royals to serve as guard rails while China had both legalist and confucianist thought - both struggled against one another for primacy but both placed some constraints on a ruler's behavior. Obviously both of these systems still struggled with corrupt and occasionally full retard rulers but Russia didn't even have this much holding the ruler in check.

>>14358774
>The Challenge, Andrew Lambert.
About the war of 1812, specifically the naval war and economic war.
>The British Way of War, Andrew Lambert. Ostensibly a biography of Sir Julian Corbett, but deals a lot with the pre-WW1 debates about national strategy in Great Britain.
>Thunder on the Danube (3 vols), John H. Gill
About the war of the war of the 5th coalition. One of the best Napoleonic campaign histories I've read.
>England in the Seven Years War: A Study in Combined Strategy (2 vols), Sir Julian S. Corbett
Title says it all, its main focus is in examining the war from a lessons learned perspective rather than a purely historical one.
>Some Principles of Maritime Strategy, Sir Julian S. Corbett
This is really a doctrinal primer from 1907, but it's very eye opening if you have any interest in historical seapower. Makes it far easier to understand the why's of many decisions at sea.
>The Roman War of Antiochus the Great, John D. Grainger
A detailed study of the conflict between Rome and the Seleucids
>Antigonus the One Eyed and the Creation of the Hellenistic State, Richard Billows
One half is a biography of Antigonus and the other half is an examination of how the Hellenistic states developed post-Alexander
>The End of the Bronze Age, Robert Drews
This is a really interesting book regarding the Bronze Age collapse, Drews argues that their was no great migration and that the sea peoples etc, were just the normal dwellers around the fringes of society who'd learnt how to destroy chariot armies and just wanted to kill, burn and maim.

>>14360815
Levy's "Conquistador" is has a fair amount of issues, I remember I read the first 10 pages or so and already noticed multiple major errors per page.

>when it was the tribes oppressed by the Mexica for years that took an opportunity to wreck vengeance on them.


This is a misconception.

There were no "tribes": Mesoamerican had urbanized state societies with cities and formal governments for thousands of years by this point. Basically every society the Aztec bothered to conquer or interact with were city-states, kingdoms., and empires;

Secondly, while the Mexica of Tenochtitlan were warmongering expansionists, they were hands off with the places they actually conquered, generally speaking. This is true of most large Mesoamerican empires, but the Aztec did things like installing rulers on conquered subjects etc less then other large Mesoamerican states: They basically just demanded taxes of economic goods, military service, and that roads not be blocked alongside a few other basic obligations, with subjects keeping their, laws, customs, etc. Sacrifices was something everybody did, and were mostly captured enemy soldiers from wars.

The reason Cortes got allies is that this hands off system enabled subject states to both act independently and have their own political ambitions, so you regularly had subjects seceding and launching coups opportunistically:

State X allying or pledging themselves as a subject to state Y (since subjects got left alone anyways) to take out their existing captial or political rivals, so then X could be in higher standing in Y's new kingdom, was a common method of political advancement. That's pretty much why Cortes and other conquistadors got allies, andt he Aztec empire itself was founded this way: Cortes was basically being used.

See: https://pastebin.com/VqW97h93

George Lloyd, former British Prime Minister noted in 1936:

“I have now seen the famous German leader and also something of the great change he has effected. He rightly claimed at Nuremberg that in four years his movement had made a new Germany. It is not the Germany of the first decade that followed the war – broken, dejected and bowed down with a sense of apprehension and impotence. It is now full of hope and confidence, and of a renewed sense of determination to lead its own life without interference from any influence outside its own frontiers.

There is for the first time since the war a general sense of security. The people are more cheerful. There is a greater sense of general gaiety of spirit throughout the land. It is a happier Germany. I saw it everywhere, and Englishmen I met during my trip and who knew Germany well were very impressed with the change.

One man has accomplished this miracle. He is a born leader of men. A magnetic and dynamic personality with a single-minded purpose, as resolute will and a dauntless heart. He is not merely in name but in fact the national Leader. He has made them safe against potential enemies by whom they were surrounded. He is also securing them against the constant dread of starvation which is one of the most poignant memories of the last years of the War and the first years of the Peace. The concept of whiteness, or the idea that certain racial or ethnic groups are superior to others based on their skin color, has a long and complex history that can be traced back to ancient civilizations. The idea of a "white race" as a distinct and superior group of people is a relatively modern construct that emerged during the Age of Enlightenment in Europe in the 18th century. During this time, European intellectuals began to develop theories about race that were based on physical characteristics, such as skin color, and used these theories to justify colonialism, slavery, and other forms of exploitation. These ideas were later adopted and adapted by other countries and cultures around the world.

The concept of whiteness has evolved over time and has been used to justify a wide range of discriminatory policies and practices, including segregation, segregation, and racism. It has also been used to perpetuate systems of privilege and power that benefit those who are considered white while disadvantaging those who are not. Today, the concept of whiteness continues to play a significant role in shaping social and political relationships and systems, and it is an important area of study in fields such as sociology, anthropology, and critical race theory.

Wrong. Proto-Uralic and proto-Altaic are obviously closely related to each other, eventhough the intricate details of their relationship aren't fully reconstructable yet. At their core, both are synthetic-agglutinative languages of the SOV type with vowel harmony and without genders.

Hinduism is not really a religion in the way we normally think of a religion (like Christianity or Islam or Buddhism).

The term "Hinduism" was coined by the British to describe the various thousands of folk religions and village cults spread throughout British India.

It would be like taking and combining Judaism, Samaritanism, Christianity, Islam, Bahai, etc and calling it all "Abrahamism" or something.

It's essentially a fake colonial term. Prior to the British, the native Indians didn't have a single term to refer to their religion in the same way Christians or Muslims might. Even the word "Hindu" is literally Persian, it is not native to India. The word "Hindu" didn't even have religious or cultural associations prior to the British, it was used more as a geographical term - even the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb referred to himself as "a Hindu" (i.e. a dweller of India).

They contribute to the production and distribution of goods and services, and they provide a source of income for individuals and families. Jobs also help to create a sense of community and belonging, and they can provide opportunities for social and professional networking.

Ultimately, the value and importance of a job will depend on the individual circumstances and perspectives of each person. It is important to consider the impact that work has on an individual's well-being and overall quality of life, and to find a job that is fulfilling and meaningful to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) considers aging to be a natural process. This makes it difficult to get FDA approval for drugs that seek to slow or reverse the biological process of aging. Instead, drugs intended to target aging must target a disease that often results from the aging process in order to demonstrate efficacy and gain approval. But there is growing consensus and effort among scientists to convince the FDA that aging itself should be classified as a disease and an appropriate target for drug development.

This could be a major milestone for not just industry, but society. If the FDA is swayed, the resulting regulatory shift could mean approval of drugs or treatments that slow or reverse the aging process generally, before a patient develops disease. Researchers who view aging as a medical condition aren't referring only to the inevitable passage of time. Instead, they view aging as a process of deterioration of our structure and function at the cellular level; the hallmark characteristics of which are genomic instability and damage to our DNA. And the World Health Organization (WHO) supports this view -- WHO describes the process of aging as "... the impact of the accumulation of a wide variety of molecular and cellular damage over time."

Because you would get outmaneuvered. Still rudamentary earthworks were part of certain field battles such as the Bagration Flèches during the Battle of Borodino.
>cover
Was used when available - so not really in an open field. But fighting in woods, hedges and houses was common. Especially houses often formed strong points in defensive positions.

Like sandbags?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mass formations were good in open fields for controlled fire. Cover was useful in some situations, but it essentially meant you would not be advancing on the enemy and you'd be surrendering initiative to them, allowing them to maneuver however they wished. This was an era where cavalry was still very important, and allowing the enemy's cavalry to have the run of the battlefield by entrenching yourself could lead to getting outflanked.

Remember this is pre-modern warfare, there's no railroads or automobiles. If you're not lucky enough to be near a navigable river or the ocean, your only line of supply is horse-drawn wagons which are ponderously slow and vulnerable to raids from, say, a bunch of cavalry you did nothing to stop outflanking you. Your entrenchment is going to look very silly in a few days once you run out of food.

If you had thrown a little more boldly in the flood of fortune
You’d have had England; or in the slackening
Less boldly, you’d not have sunk your right hand in Russia: these
Are the two ghosts; they stand by the bed
And make a man tear his flesh. The rest is fatal; each day
A new disaster, and at last Vae Victis,
It means Weh den Gesiegten. This is the essence of tragedy,
To have meant well and made woe, and watch Fate,
All stone, approach.

But tragedy has obligations. A choice
Comes to each man when his days darken:
To be tragic or to be pitiful. You must do nothing pitiful.
Suicide, which no doubt you contemplate,
Is not enough, suicide is for bankrupt shopkeepers.
You should be Samson, blind Samson, crushing
All his foes, that’s Europe, America, half Asia, in his fall.
But you are not able; and the tale is Hebrew.

I have seen a wing-broken hawk, standing in her own dirt,
Helpless, a caged captive, with cold
Indomitable eyes of disdain, meet death. There was nothing pitiful,
No degradation, but eternal defiance.
Or a sheepfold harrier, a grim, grey wolf, hunted all day,
Wounded, struck down at the turn of twilight,
How grandly he dies. The pack whines in a ring and not closes,
The head lifts, the great fangs grin, the hunters
Admire their victim. That is how you should end — for they prophesied
You would die like a dog — like a wolf, war-loser.

June, 1943

I visited a chabad a synagogue for a school project. It was close to where I live in Utah and I thought it'd be interesting. I emailed the rabbi before going asking if he'd mind and what's appropriate. He was kind of cold and straight forward. I went shabbat eve and shabbat morning. There were primarily ashkenazi jews, some dressed in hasidic clothes, most not. There were some sephardi and mizrahi jews, some in hasidic clothes. Some yiddish phrases were thrown around. Some Jews were sort of "Professional Jews" in that they took their Jewishness seriously, others were more normie Jews that sort of showed up because that's just what they did.
Shabbat eve was sort of this informal Jewish party time where Jews in street clothes came from work or school and they all sang and dance. They did this weird conga line type thing around the main lectern in the center of the room. The rabbi very begrudgingly waved for me to join them, which I did. The Jews there were generally very friendly toward me until I told them I wasn't a Jew and was just visiting, then their smiles would fade and become like the rabbi's. The shabbat morning was more familiar to me. It was more formal and solemn but still kind of happy. The meeting was all centered around bringing the Torah out of the ark and quasi royal pomp and circumstance where they took turns cradling it. Then they unrolled it and took turns reading from it aloud. I think they sung some psalms and did that whole quaking thing where they rock back and forth while they do it. At the very end the rabbi gave some short spiel in English related to what they just read and sort of connected it to what was going on in their community. The passage they read was about Abraham going to Canaan and so he likened it to a Jewish couple they knew in the community that was making aliyah. While I never felt so out of place in my life at the time, I enjoyed it in hindsight just because it was cool to see.

I'm very frustrated at the lack of material on Syrian military involvement in the Gulf War, and Iraq-Syria border incidents during the Iran-Iraq War.

For the former all I can find is that roughly 30 Iraqis stormed Syrian positions in Saudi Arabia on February 6th with mixed results, that Syria partook in the liberation of Kuwait wherein one soldier was killed and two wounded by mines, and that Syrian AAA opened up on allied USAF F-117 at one point.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/27/world/after-the-war-syria-plans-to-double-gulf-force.html
https://theaviationgeekclub.com/the-unknown-story-of-the-f-117-that-was-shot-at-by-syrian-aaa-during-operation-desert-storm/

For the latter, I found out through my own research that Tom Cooper's numbers on Syrian aircraft down by Iraq during the Iran-Iraq War was false; the only truly confirmed 'confirmed' kill from his list was a MiG-21 shot down by AAA in 1988.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14367047
United States - unparalleled manufacturing ability led to vast numbers of "good enough" tanks meant to be survivable and comfortable and safe; they were frequently outmatched in terms of pure technical capability in a 1-on-1 fight, but the fights were almost never 1-on-1
Germany - best tanks on paper with maximal armor, speed, controls, safety, weaponry, range, etc.; unfortunately Germany had few resources so they couldn't make very many of them, and they frequently turned out to be less functional in the field than they were on the testing grounds, with mud clogging their overdesigned swiss-clock internals and running out of gas and ammo turning them into sitting ducks
Soviet Union - very poor production standards meant that these tanks were usually death traps but with American lend-lease supplies they were able to produce and field so many of them that they were able to overwhelm Germany; essentially a bad tank that works is better than a good tank that doesn't
Britain - like America, but in every sense of the word, "less"
Italy - what happens when your country has fallen behind the rest of the world militarily for the past 500 years? tanks made by people who don't know how to use them - a joke
Japan - what happens when your tiny island country just needs to run over unarmed chinks? tanks made by people who don't know how to make them - an even bigger joke

>>14360812
>In russia (granted, I'm sure there are plenty of russians who really fucking hate stalin and the communists) some look at stalin as good for keeping the germans from exterminating the russians
Oh yeah he definitely has his haters in Russia too. But yeah that, and he's like Napoleon really. He was a bad guy who murdered people and destroyed nations, but he also laid the foundations for the modern Russian state (which does bear its markings even though it's no longer "communist") and spread his ideals beyond his country's borders where they still persist in a form in China. The CPSU itself also outlasted him.

Hitler was just a counter-revolutionary and his regime was totally destroyed. Stalin was more complex because he was a revolutionary but also one that reversed some of it in a half-conservative way like Napoleon did who crowned himself emperor. I buy the theory that Stalinism was a weird paradox of an ideology because it was Marxism adapting itself to a society that had barely emerged from feudalism, so the Communist Party accelerated and powered that society into industrialization, but it adopted an "Asiatic" (ehh) or "magical" superstructure much like a pre-capitalist civilization with Stalin rendered much like Akhenaten or an ancient Sun God. That allowed it to hold together during this process in the 1930s-1940s.

Most normies today would recoil in disgust at this regime, and there are parts of it that do read like a horror novel. But I think it "made sense" (logically, if not "rationally") for such a society undergoing such a transition at that time, and its own success -- industrialization and the entrance into modernity -- rendered it obsolete.

One problem ideologically is that if you're used to treating Stalin as a demigod, then there's a big crisis when he dies, so I think modern-day "Stalinists" are kinda like the equivalent of a cargo cult in Ancient Egypt that went around proclaiming Akhenaten as their God decades after he died.

posts.com:
What would a modern day Maginot line look like?

Let's say a hypothetical non-nuclear wealthy nation somewhere in east Europe is looking to boost its defense with a massive fortified wall on one of its borders (a flat open border with no natural geographical barriers).

What would be the best material to make this out of (dirt, rebar, steel)? What angle should the wall have (30 degrees and shallow or flat 90 degrees walls like a typical modern bunker)? Should it zig-zag or run straight (is enfilading fire worth the extra length it would to such a construction)? What about large anti-air towers dotted through-out the likes of which we saw in WWII in Germany (or do modern air defense systems negate the need for towers)? How tall does it need to be (does height even matter)?

I understand a tempting answer to these questions might be: a wall is not a cost-effective defensive option. And I agree, however, it's a hard static defense at the border, which is tempting because it offers the hope that the homeland of this hypothetical nation might avoid protracted land-war altogether.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14366845
Similar to the albanian bunker program under Hoxha but with more elaborate underground facilities of said hypothetical nation wants those bunker complexes to be more self reliant.
>material
>angle
>zig-zag
These are more of a question for engineers. It depends on the type of bunker, what it should house, what it is expected to fight against, what it should withstand, etx. An infantry bunker is different than an artillery bunker. What is the geographic makeup and was some degree earthworks established?
>What about large anti-air towers
Well I'm no expert on that matter but I doubt that modern missle systems can operate without any form of radar guidance. And I doubt that a radar could operate within a concrete tower - it has to be outside. The only good thing is that those towers are high so that the radar-superstructure (which can be destroyed as it is outide) has a good foundation.
>it's a hard static defense at the border, which is tempting because it offers the hope that the homeland of this hypothetical nation might avoid protracted land-war altogether.
The maginot line did not have the intention to hold the enemy indefinitely until they were beaten but to delay them and to let them suffer attrition so that a decisive french counterattack could be commenced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In terms of making the best use of limited budget, the "maginot line" would lean more towards infrastructure, decoys, supply caches, counter-battery fire and various modern things like electronic warfare, anti-air and missile defense. Concealment would be more important than fortifications. You can build the deepest bunker with the thickest reinforced concrete, but if the enemy knows where it is they can overwhelm it. Even if this does not totally destroy the installation, it can damage it enough to prevent it from firing and interfering with their assault.

The goal is to win the artillery duel, for artillery to be able to "shoot and scoot" with ease, ample radar to detect the flight of enemy shells and determine their origin which turns on and off while another turns on to take its place at random intervals making it difficult for the radar to be located, for supplies to be quickly delivered and well secured with multiple supply routes, numerous caches and few chokepoints that might be put out of action for long. Good communications so artillery can retrieve supplies from said caches. The bunkers themselves don't need to be giants, just allow the occupants to withstand a shelling (and be able to get out afterwards) and not look much different from the decoys which the enemy will be wasting their shells on, assuming they are discovered.
